nodes.title: II.2. Superficial structures: Primarily funerary superstructure
Oral tradition
nodes.body: Local sources commonly believe that Gyangro NadongGyang ro sna gdongis the ruins of a Buddhist monastery destroyed by the 18th century CE jun gar. At some point in history, the funerary identity of the site receded from the collective memory and was replaced with this apocryphal tale. The fear of archaic cultural burial sites must have played a role in he recasting of Gyangro NadongGyang ro sna gdong’s identity. This reconfiguration of the cultural significance of the site, however, is not complete. Certain drok pa’brog pa elders report that square burial chambers were found inside some of the erraced structures, and that the interred corpses were adorned with patterned agates and coral. The locations of ombs that were opened are no longer clear. The use of funerary structure FS2 as a sky burial site also indicates hat the funerary function of the site was never fully forgotten.
